title: 106_s2605
content: The "Commercial Fishermen Safety and Tax Fairness Act of 2000" allows income averaging for fishermen by amending the Internal Revenue Code to include fishing business. The definition of elected farm income now includes fishing business, and a new definition for fishing business is provided as the conduct of commercial fishing as defined in the Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act. The Commercial Fishermen Safety and Tax Fairness Act of 2000 includes a new section in the Internal Revenue Code for a Fishing Safety Equipment Credit under SEC. 45D. The Commercial Fishermen Safety and Tax Fairness Act of 2000 introduced a Fishing Safety Equipment Credit under SEC. 45D. The credit allows eligible taxpayers engaged in a fishing business to claim 75% of qualified fishing safety equipment expenses, not exceeding $1,500 per year. Qualified expenses include lifesaving equipment required on vessels. The Fishing Safety Equipment Credit introduced under SEC. 45D allows eligible taxpayers in the fishing business to claim 75% of qualified safety equipment expenses, up to $1,500 per year. Special rules apply, including aggregation rules for persons treated as a single employer. No double benefit deduction is allowed, and the basis of equipment is adjusted if a credit is claimed. Carryback of the fishing safety equipment credit is not permitted. The Fishing Safety Equipment Credit introduced under SEC. 45D allows eligible taxpayers in the fishing business to claim 75% of qualified safety equipment expenses, up to $1,500 per year. Special rules apply, including aggregation rules for persons treated as a single employer. No double benefit deduction is allowed, and the basis of equipment is adjusted if a credit is claimed. Carryback of the fishing safety equipment credit is not permitted. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 include prohibiting the carryback of the fishing safety equipment credit before the effective date and making conforming amendments to sections 38(b) and 1016. The Fishing Safety Equipment Credit under SEC. 45D allows taxpayers in the fishing business to claim a credit for qualified safety equipment expenses. A clerical amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Fishing Safety Equipment Credit under SEC. 45D applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2000.
